############################################################################### # # # Alteeve's Niche! #!string!brand_0002!# Configuration # # # # This is the global configuration for the #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard and alert # # monitoring system. Once configured on a dashboard, you can copy it as-is to # # your nodes. # # # ###############################################################################

### Global - These values apply to all #!string!brand_0004!# systems, unless overridden.
# This configures how email is sent from this machine. Please be sure to set # the values below to the values given to you by your mail administrator (if # that's not you). # # This is the mail server to connect to when sending email. smtp::server = #!variable!smtp__server!#
# This is the TCP port used to connect to the mail server. smtp::port = #!variable!smtp__port!#
# This is the email address/IMAP user to send to the mail server. It is also # the address used in the 'From: ' field for emails sent from this machine. # NOTE: If you IMAP user name is not an email address, this may not work (it # has not been tested). If you have trouble, please let us know: # - #!string!brand_0012!# smtp::username = #!variable!smtp__username!#
# This is the password used for the email account above. This can be the # password directly, or a file that contains the password. #smtp::password = file:./email_pw.txt smtp::password = #!variable!smtp__password!#
# This is the security level to use when connecting to the peer, if needed. smtp::security = #!variable!smtp__security!#
# This tells us to use an encrypted connection to the mail server. Set to '0' # to send email plain-text (not recommended!). smtp::encrypt_pass = #!variable!smtp__encrypt_pass!#
# This is the domain given to the mail server when establishing the connection. smtp::helo_domain = #!variable!smtp__helo_domain!#
# This is a comma-separated list of email recipients. Please use bare email # addresses only. mail_data::to = #!variable!mail_data__to!#
# This sets the 'sending domain' when sending email. It should match # smtp::server in most cases. mail_data::sending_domain = #!variable!mail_data__sending_domain!#
### Per-#!string!brand_0004!# Configurations
# This defines each #!string!brand_0004!#. If you want to defined multiple #!string!brand_0004!#s in #!string!brand_0002!#, # copy an entry in this section and increment the variable integer. The order # and value do not matter. It's simply a differentiator. If only one entry # exists, #!string!brand_0002!#'s #!string!brand_0004!# selection screen will not show and the sole entry # will be auto-selected. # # name: Must match the name set in the #!string!brand_0004!#'s 'cluster.conf' file. # nodes: A comma-separated list of nodes. On the #!string!brand_0002!# server, this must # be resolvable to the target machine (ie: via /etc/hosts + # /etc/ssh/ssh_config) # company: A free-form field used to show the owner of the #!string!brand_0004!#. # Particularly useful for resellers and companies with divisions. # description: Also a free-form field used to describe the purpose of the # particular #!string!brand_0004!#. # url: If defined, a link to the given URL will be shown beside the # #!string!brand_0004!#'s name in the Dashboard's #!string!brand_0004!# selection screen. Useful # for linking to internal documentation or similar. # ricci_pw: This is the password used by the 'ricci' user on the #!string!brand_0004!#'s # nodes. It must be set accurately in order to add or remove # servers. If the 'root_pw' is not set below, this password will # be used. # root_pw: This password is used by the dashboard to log into this #!string!brand_0004!#'s # nodes.
### Last updated: #!variable!date!#

############################################################################## # Please do not put any variables other than 'Host' sections below here. # # At this time, only 'Host / Port' is supported. Please use ~/.ssh/config if # # you need to specify additional options for a given host. # ##############################################################################

# The file is maintained by #!string!brand_0002!#. If you modify this manually, entries will # be preserved but formatting and comments will not. ::1 localhost localhost.localdomain localhost6 localhost6.localdomain6
Do not edit this file! Changes will be lost when #!string!brand_0002!# re-writes it.
Last updated: #!variable!date!#.

### #!string!brand_0001!# - Generated on: [#!variable!date_and_time!#] by: [#!variable!program!#]. # This is an autogenerated file. Manual change should be preserved when it is # updated but bugs may exist. Backups will be created with the date and time as # the file name suffix. If manually added values are lost, please contact # support: #!string!brand_0012!#
::1 localhost6 localhost6.localdomain6

This is the name of your #!string!brand_0003!#'s cluster name.
This is set in cluster.conf in the <cluster ...> element's name="..." attribute.
This is a free-form text field where you can put in any description you would like for the #!string!brand_0003!#.
If you have an internal tracking or documentation system, and if you track the given #!string!brand_0003!# there, you can enter the URL for it here.

This is the name of the company, person or group that owns the specified #!string!brand_0003!#.
This is a purely descriptive field and you can set it to whatever you want.
Add a new #!string!brand_0003!#, edit an existing one or delete a retired system.

This is the password used to log into your #!string!brand_0003!# nodes.
If you built your #!string!brand_0003!# manually, this is the password used for the 'ricci' and 'root' users, which must match.
The host names of the nodes. Generally, this is xx-aYYnZZ.

Generally, if this machine is in the same place as the the #!string!brand_0003!#, the name you set here will resolve to the '#!string!brand_0005!#' of the node.
If the nodes are on a remote network, and if you (or the owner's admin) setup port forwarding, you will enter their external IP address for both nodes and use different ports.
If you use DNS (or similar) to do name to IP translation, leave this blank.

This is the TCP port used to connect to the node over SSH. If you do not specify this, port 22 will be used.
If the nodes are behind a firewall though, you may need to specify specific port numbers in order to reach each node.
When in doubt, leave this blank.

The dashboard does not send email, but your #!string!brand_0003!# nodes will.
The #!conf!path::config_file!# that this section manages is designed to be copied unchanged to your nodes, so this information is needed to send alert emails later.

This is the mail server that your node will connect to in order to send email.
Your Internet service provider will give you this address, often called an "SMTP Server".

When connecting to the mail server address above, a specific "port" number must be specified.
Your ISP should mention what this port number along with the address.
Typically, this is "25" for unencrypted connections and "587" for encrypted connections.
Edit, add or delete #!string!brand_0003!# owners.

Some mail server require a user name and password. Usually, the user name will be you email address.
Some ISPs do not require authentication, and in those cases, this can be left blank.
Please check the information given to you by your ISP to see if this is needed and, if so, what user name to user here.
If you entered a user name above, please enter it's password here.

This controls how, if at all, to encrypt the email traffic between you and the mail server.
As with the other mail settings, which to use will depends on your Internet service provider.
If in doubt, try 'STARTTLS'. If that doesn't work, try 'SSL/TLS'. If that still doesn't work, try 'None'.

This controls whether your password is sent to the mail server in plain text or encrypted.
Most modern mail servers support encrypted passwords, so 'Yes' should work here.

This is the person or list of people who will get alert emails. Please enter just the email address.
Separate multiple email addresses with a comma please.
Example: 'foo@example.com, bar@example.com'.
Any existing open connections to servers may need to be reopened.
The physical disks below are not currently a member of any logical disk.
The server is shut off.
I am sorry, but without this information, I can not continue.
Configure mail server(s) to use when sending alert emails.

This can be whatever you want, but it must be unique.
It's good to keep this short.

This fine-tunes the hypervisor for your operating system.
If your OS is not listed, choose the one that is the closest match.

This will open a new window where you can upload new disc images.
Once finished, please reload this page to see them.
You server will boot and install of this disc.
This is optional.

If you need a drivers to install your server,
please select the appropriate disc here.
Most servers work well between 2 and 8 GiB.
Windows servers tend to work best with 2 CPUs.
More is not always better. When in doubt, start with 2 to 4. You can change this easily later.
Please use only one node's storage pool.
Enter a fixed size or a percentage of remaining free space to use for this server.
This is likely a bug in the program.

Save the current configuration of this #!string!brand_0002!# to a file on your computer.
This can be used to restore the configuration should this dashboard get reset or replaced.

If you upload a backup configuration file, any existing configuration will be removed and the information in the backup file will be loaded.
Generally, this is done when a dashboard is fresh and there is no existing configuration.
If you have a configuration already that you do not want to lose, please do not use this feature.
It would appear that no file was uploaded.
The file #!variable!file!# does not appear to be a valid backup file.
The mimetype detected was #!variable!mimetype!#. The backup file should be 'text/plain'.
The backup file is expected to start with '<!-- Striker Backup -->'.
The "#!variable!field!#" must be a fully qualified domain name. If you do not want to use your domain name, use x.localdomain or similar.
The backup configuration has been loaded!
Downloading a file from the internet can take a long time!
Please be sure that the web address above is a direct link to the file you want to download.
Some webistes use referal links which may not work here.
If the file you download doesn't work, please delete it from the #!string!brand_0003!# and then download the file yourself.
Once you have the file, you can upload it to the #!string!brand_0003!# from your computer.
This could take a while if the file is big and if your network is slow.
If this is a USB drive, it may have been unplugged.
This could take over ten minutes, depending on the size of the disc and the speed of your optical drive.
Uploading image file: #!variable!name!# to the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
This could take a long time, depending on the speed of the connection between #!string!brand_0020!# and the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This process could take quite some time to complete!
This action can not be undone!
It is possible that another user deleted this file already.
#!string!symbol_0012!# By default, ~256 MiB is set aside for the file system journals.

Once a file transfer starts, it will continue even if you close the page
or the connection times out. If you wish to end the transfer, at this time,
you will need to restart the web server or reboot the dashboard server.
Asking dd to create an image of: [#!variable!device!#] called: [#!variable!name!#] in the: [#!variable!directory!#] directory.

This form is used for creating an #!string!brand_0003!# installation manifest file.
The manifest will be saved locally and can be used later to build new #!string!brand_0003!# system or rebuild/replace a node.

This is a short prefix that describes the owner or department of this #!string!brand_0003!#.
Generally it is two or three characters long and often is an acronym for the company or department.
This is, ultimately, a free-form field to set as you wish. Please only use alphanumeric characters.
This is the company or department domain name. It will be appended to all host names.

This is a sequence number for this #!string!brand_0003!#.
It is combined with the prefix above and, combined, must be unique across your network(s).
Note: Auto-generating IPs only works up to '25. Beyond that, you need to manually specify the node IPs.
Fill out the rest of the form using default values combined with the "#!string!title_0150!#" answers above.

This is the IP address block and subnet for the #!string!brand_0005!#.
The left field is the network block, ie: 10.20.0.0, and the right field is the subnet mask, ie: 255.255.0.0.

This is the IP address block and subnet for the #!string!brand_0007!#.
The left field is the network block, ie: 10.10.0.0, and the right field is the subnet mask, ie: 255.255.0.0.

This is the IP address block and subnet for the #!string!brand_0009!#.
The left field is the network block, ie: 10.255.0.0, and the right field is the subnet mask, ie: 255.255.0.0.
This is the host name for the first #!string!brand_0003!# node.
This is the host name for the second #!string!brand_0003!# node.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0005!# interface.
This is the network that will be used for cluster communication, management, fencing and live-migration traffic.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0007!# interface.
This is the network that all storage data is replicated over.

This is the IP address and the subnet of the node's #!string!brand_0009!# interface.
This is the network all the traffic to and from your servers will travel over.

The IP address of the node's IPMI Interface.
It may be called by other names, like "iRMC", "iLO", "iDRAC", "RSA" or so on, depending on your hardware vendor.
This will be the node's primary fence method.
This is the host name for the first UPS.

The IP address of the first UPS.
If you don't have a UPS, or your UPS does not have a network card, you can leave this blank.
This is the host name for the second UPS.

The IP address of the second UPS.
If you don't have two UPSes, or your UPSes do not have network cards, you can leave this blank.
This is the host name for the first Switched PDU.

The IP address of the first switched PDU.
This is part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.
This is the host name for the second Switched PDU.

The IP address of the second switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.

This is the host name for the first network switch.
If you manage your switches using a serial interface, or if your switches are unmanaged, you can leave this blank.

The IP address of the first network switch.
This isn't very important and can safely be left blank.
It is helpful in that it will add an entry to each node's '/etc/hosts making it easier to connect to it using it's host name.

This is the host name for the second network switch.
It may only be useful if you break the switch stack, and can often be safely omitted.

The IP address of the second network switch.
This isn't very important and can safely be left blank, particularly in stacked switch environments.
It is helpful in that it will add an entry to each node's '/etc/hosts making it easier to connect to it using it's host name.

This is the host name for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard.
This name, along with the IP addresses below, is used to populate each node's "/etc/hosts" file.
It serves no other purpose and can be left blank if you prefer not to set it.
This is the IP address for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0005!# connection.
This is the IP address for the first #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0009!# connection.

This is the host name for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard, if you have one.
This name, along with the IP addresses below, is used to populate each node's "/etc/hosts" file.
It serves no other purpose and can be left blank if you prefer not to set it.
This is the IP address for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0005!# connection.
This is the IP address for the second #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard's #!string!brand_0009!# connection.

This is the default gateway used to access the Internet on the #!string!brand_0009!# interface.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the primary domain name server used to resolve hostnames to IP address when the given host name was not found in /etc/hosts.
The default IP address of 8.8.8.8 is one of Google's open DNS servers.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the secondary domain name server used to resolve hostnames to IP address when the given host name was not found in /etc/hosts.
The default IP address of 8.8.4.4 is the other of Google's open DNS servers.
If your nodes will not have access to the Internet, you can leave this blank.

This is the name of this #!string!brand_0003!# in the HA cluster stack's /etc/cluster/cluster.conf file. It must be 15 alphanumeric characters or less.
Generally it will be in the format "<prefix>-#!string!brand_0013!#-<sequence>".

If one of the node's power supplies are plugged into this PDU, enter the outlet number that the power cord is plugged into here.
WARNING: It is very important that this is correct!

This can be used to specify a primary (or sole) internal NTP server if your #!string!brand_0003!# doesn't have access to external time servers.
If you don't have an internal NTP server, leave this blank.
This can be used to specify a backup NTP server, if available.

The "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid IP address or domain name.
Please enter the value as a domain name or IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty.

When an #!string!brand_0003!# node starts, it will boot any servers that it finds powered off
unless is was gracefully shut down by a user. You can use this option to create a boot order
and timing. The left field can be a delay (in seconds) to wait before this server is booted.
If set to '#!string!title_0105!#', the server will not be booted.
The "#!variable!field!#" must be an integer (whole number).
The "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid domain name.

The "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid IP address.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".
Add, edit and remove alert notification targets.
#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty.
#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid domain name.
#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" must be the number of the outlet that the node's PSU is plugged into.

#!variable!node!#'s "#!variable!field!#" does not appear to be a valid IP address with subnet mask.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address followed by a subnet mask in either dotted-decimal or CIDR format.
The format should be either "a.b.c.d/x" or "a.b.c.d/w.x.y.z".

This will set the password for multiple components of the #!string!brand_0003!#;
It will set each node's "root" and "ricci" users and the IPMI user's password.
This doesn't have to match the password you set for this #!string!brand_0002!#, but generally it sould.
Note: The password will be echoed back to you!
This is needed because the different passwords to set do not share a common encryption form.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty when the IP address is set.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty when the host name is set.

Review the values above. Once you are happy that they are accurate,
press #!string!button_0047!# and the install manifest will be created for you.

This is the amount of space that will be allocated to the "#!string!button_0023!#".
This is where install discs, driver disks and so on are stored for use in servers later.
Generally, the default of 40 GiB is plenty. However, if you only plan to install one type of server, this can be reduced.
On the other hand, if you plan to install many different operating systems on your servers, you may wish to make this larger.

This is the amount of space to allocate to the first storage pool on your #!string!brand_0003!#.
This can be specified as a percentage of the free space, or you can set it to a specific size.
Which ever you choose, the difference will be used to determine the size of the second storage pool automatically.
If you set a static size equal to or larger than the actually available space, or if you choose 100 %, no second storage pool will be created.
The "#!variable!field!#" address block value can not be empty.
The "#!variable!field!#" subnet mask value can not be empty.

The "#!variable!field!#" address block does not appear to be a valid IP address.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".

The "#!variable!field!#" subnet mask does not appear to be a valid IP address.
Please enter the value as an IPv4 address in the format "a.b.c.d".
The "#!variable!field!#" value must be between 0 and 100 when the units are % (percentage).
The "#!variable!field!#" must be an integer (whole number) or a floating point (number with a decimal) value.
The "#!variable!field!#" can not be longer than 15 characters.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can only contain alphanumeric characters and dashes (-).
The install manifest has been saved successfully.

Have you reviewed the values that will be set carefully?

If you are happy, enter the current IP address and the current root user's password for both nodes.
This is a new install, so storage will be initialized and any existing data will be lost!

During the install process, the nodes may be rebooted to load a new kernel, if updated, or to reconfigure the network, if needed.

If, for some reason, this #!string!brand_0002!# dashboard can not access the nodes after they reboot, manual intervention will be required.

This installation process might take quite some time to complete, depending on multiple factors like your network speed, machine speed, etc.

Please be patient while the process runs and do not interrupt the process once it has started.

Please be patient!

Some tasks may not cause any output to be displayed for some time.

Please do not reload this page!.

The next step will install required programs on the nodes.
This might take a while on slow Internet connections.
Please be patient!
If you think the system is hung, please log into the nodes and run:
ps aux | grep yum
If you see yum running, then please keep waiting.

The next step will try to update the operating system on the nodes.
This might take a while on slow Internet connections.
Please be patient!
As above, use ps auxf as above.
Now that we've had a chance to look at your hardware, we're ready to install!
Please review the build plan below and, if you're happy, press "#!string!button_0053!#".
If the storage is OK, but you want to remap the network, press "#!string!button_0054!#".
If the storage is not OK, please edit the install manifest by pressing "#!string!button_0055!#".

In order to access the Red Hat network to download packages, you must register your nodes against RHN.
You haven't yet, so you can enter your credentials below and we will register before installing packages.
Please note that this will consume a "Resilient Storage" and the "Optional" repository will be enabled per node.
If registration fails for some reason, the installer will try to proceed anyway.

The install manifest file: [#!variable!file!#] has been generated.
It is a copy of: [#!variable!old_manifest!#] but with the network mapping recorded.
Use this new one in the future to avoid the manual network mapping step.

The install is now beginning. Sanity checks will re-run, just to be safe.
Configuration will begin automatically after that.
Now is a good time to go have a $drink.

The node(s) will now be registered with RHN.
This process can take a minute or two, so please be patient.

If you have custom or local repositories for installing programs on the #!string!brand_0003!# nodes, you can define them here.
This can be one or more URL to the repository file (ie: https://alteeve.ca/repo/el6/an.repo).
Use a comma without spaces to specify two or more repositories.
The "#!variable!field!#" must be a valid URL.

If either node needs to be rebooted, it will be done now.
If both nodes need to be rebooted, they will be rebooted sequentially.
Each node will be given #!conf!sys::reboot_timeout!# seconds to successfully reboot.
If either node fails to reboot in this period of time, the install will abort.
If this happens, the other node should be accessible and may provide a way to resolve the problem.
The "#!variable!field!#" value can not be empty if the field "#!variable!dependent_field!#" is set.
In a two-PDU environment, then both must be defined. In a four PDU environment, at least two must be defined.
#!variable!node!# is set to use an outlet on "#!variable!field!#", but that PDU doesn't have a name and IP set.
#!variable!node!# needs to have outlets set for two PDUs.
This is the host name for the third Switched PDU.

The IP address of the third switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.
This is the host name for the fourth Switched PDU.

The IP address of the fourth switched PDU.
This is the other part of the backup fence method, so making sure this is right is also very important.
Also carefully note which outlet powers which node, you will need to enter that information further below.

This is the brand name for the first Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.

This is the brand name for the second Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.

This is the brand name for the third Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.

This is the brand name for the fourth Switched PDU.
This sets which fence agent will be used to control this device if a fence action is required.
The UPSes will now be told to power cycle.
The UPSes will now be told to power off.

The MTU, or "Maximum Tranmission Unit", indicates the largest amount of data that can be sent in a given "packet" of data on a network.
In most cases, leave this as '1500'.
If you are certain all of your network equipment supports a higher MTU though, increasing this may improve performance.
Warning: Do NOT change this unless you know for sure that the larger size will be supported!
The "#!variable!field!#" is too small. The smallest valid MTU size is '576' (see RFC 879).

This controls how a server migrates to the peer node.
If it is "#!string!state_0126!#", the server is migrated while it is running, without service interruption.
In some rare cases, a "#!string!state_0127!#" migration, where the server is gracefully shut down
and then rebooted on the new node, may be preferred.

You can select a script to run before migrating a server.
The text field to the right can be used to pass arguments to your script

You can select a script to run after migrating a server.
The text field to the right can be used to pass arguments to your script

Note: 'Pre' and 'Post' migration scripts are not triggered on a normal boot or recovery.
Scripts can be uploaded in the #!string!button_0023!#.
This is the host name for the first power transfer switch.

The IP address of the first power transfer switch.
If you don't have a PTS, or your PTS does not have a network card, you can leave this blank.

When the name of the notification target. If the target is an email address, this is used in the 'To:' field.

This is the target of the alerts. This can be an email address or a file name.
If it is a file name, the alerts will go to /var/log/ on the machine generating the alert.

This is the language that alerts will be sent using.
Note: At this time, only 'English (Canadian)' is complete.

Debug level is useful for developers trouble-shooting problems with #!string!brand_0015!# or agents.
It will generate an alert on every state change resulting in an extremely high number of alerts.
Information level will generate alerts on state changes that are almost always harmless.

Notice level is the lowest level most regular users will be interested in.
It includes events like server migrations, UPS self-tests and so forth.

Warning level is the level where most technical staff will want to use.
Alerts that may indicate pending issues, like hard drive pre-failure alerts, will use this level.

Critical alerts are what non-technical staff will be interested in.
These are alerts generated by actual component failure, node loss/fence, etc.

Internally, #!string!brand_0015!# uses metric measurements.
If you prefer, you can set this to imperial and values with be converted for the recipient.
All alerts from the #!string!brand_0003!# will be ignored.
A place for you to keep any notes you wish about this alert recipient.
Note: This sets the default alert level and can be overridden for a given #!string!brand_0003!# system.

Create a new server on the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#
You will need to answer some questions in order to create a new server.
If you are unsure what a certain question means, please don't hesitate to ask questions.
#!variable!node_name!# will leave the #!string!brand_0003!#.
Once withdrawn, it will no longer be able to run or recover any servers until it rejoins the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This will attempt to join the node #!variable!node_name!# to the #!string!brand_0003!#.
This is usually a safe action.
If, for any reason, this node can't connect to it's peer, the peer node could be fenced (forcibly shut off).
This will attempt to join both nodes of the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
The #!string!brand_0003!# node #!variable!node_name!# is about to be forcibly powered off!
This will effectively press and hold your node's power button until the system is forced to power down.
Should that fail, the power to the node will be completely cut off.
This should be done as a last resort, when all other attempts to gracefully shut down the node have failed.
Every operating system has a chance of corrupting when it is forcibly powered off.
This will send a poweroff command to the #!variable!node_name!# node.
If all is well, this node should gracefully power off.
If there is a problem with this node, like an incomplete withdrawl from the #!string!brand_0003!#, it may hang while trying to shut down.
If this happens, return to the previous page and call a fence action against this node.
An attempt will be made to power on the #!variable!node_name!# node.
An attempt will be made to boot both nodes in the #!variable!anvil!# #!string!brand_0003!#.
Please be patient, it can take a few minutes for the nodes to become accessible.

Before proceeding, it is strongly advised that you connect to the server.

This will ensure that server shuts down cleanly.

This should be done as a last resort, when all other attempts to gain control of the server have failed.

By default, #!string!brand_0002!# tries to minimize the risk of interfering with your network
by enabling the install manifest feature on the #!string!brand_0005!# only.

Likewise, if the #!string!brand_0005!# is not isolated, your new node or #!string!brand_0002!# machine
may get an IP address from another machine on your network and fail to install off of this #!string!brand_0002!# machine.
If you're having trouble with this feature, please feel free to contact support.

If you a node was part of an #!string!brand_0003!# before, it might be seeing
the old LVM signature from the previous install. There is no safe way to determine
if this is the case, or if this partition contains real data. So for safety, the
install will now abort. If you are sure that there is no data on the partition, you
can wipe any data using the 'dd' command. To do this, you need to log into the
node(s) and run:

dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/X bs=4M count=1000

Where '/dev/X' is replaced by the device in the error(s) above.
BE WARNED!
The above command, if misused, can destroy all data on the node!

This program sets up passwordless SSH to the nodes associated with the given '--anvil X' switch. This is designed to allow Virtual Machine Manager the ability to access servers on the nodes without repeated request to enter the nodes' password.

SWITCHES
--anvil
This is the name of the #!string!brand_0004!# to use. The associated nodes are found by reading #!data!path::striker_config!#.
The nodes are then configured to accept all local users ssh access without a password.

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program merges the local #!data!path::striker_config!# with the one on the named peer dashboard.
Where conflicts exist, the values in the '--prefer [local|peer]' dashboard will be used.
SWITCHES
--peer <hostname or IP>
This disables the hostname or IP address of the peer dashboard to sync with.
If --peer and/or --password are not given, the program will try to determine the peer by checking:
scancore::db::x::host
If there are two entries and the local host name is found, the other will be used as the peer.
--password
This is the (root) password needed to connect to the peer.
If the peer is found in 'scancore::db::x::host' (either via --peer or detected as described above) and --password is not set, the password will be set by:
scancore::db::x::password
--prefer [local|peer]
This controls which node's data will be used if a conflict is detected.
If this is not set, 'local' will be used by default.
--force
This will prevent the program from confirming with the user before running. It is needed if the program is run by another program.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program checks to see if it can talk to the peer node on boot. If it can, it performs a series of sanity checks to make sure everything is healthy. If all is well, the nodes will start the cluster stack and then servers will be booted.
Servers that were gracefully shut down, and servers set to never boot, will be skipped.
SWITCHES
--abort
This will cause any running instances of this program to be killed.
--disable
Prevent this tool from starting on boot. Be sure to disable it on BOTH nodes!
--enable
Enable this tool on boot. Note that if this is enable on either node, the #!string!brand_0004!# will be started.
--force
Normally, if another instance of this program is already running, this instance will immediately exit. Using this switch skips this check and forces the instance to run. Be careful using this!
--state, --status
Reports whether this tool is enabled on boot or not.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program shuts down an #!string!brand_0004!# node.
Which node shuts down depends on how it is invoked. If it is invoked with '--local', the local machine will be shut down *unless* it is the SyncSource for the peer (it has data on the replicated storage the peer doesn't). In such a case, the program will throw an error and exit with a non-0 exit code.
If it is invoked with '--shed-load', then which node shuts down depends on several criteria in a certain priority order.
1. Can the peer be reached? If not, load shedding is aborted (as it is assumed the peer is already offline, in this context).
2. If one node is the 'SyncSource' for the other, then the Inconsistent peer will be shut down.
NOTE: if *both* nodes are SyncSource (on different storage pools), the load shed will throw an error and exit with a non-0 exit code.
3. If both nodes are UpToDate, and one node's health is not 'OK', then the sick node will be shut down.
4. If both nodes are UpToDate and healthy, the the sum of the RAM used by servers on each node is added. The node with the least amount of RAM used by servers will shutdown.
5. If the RAM in use by servers on both nodes is the same, node 2 will shut down.
In all cases, the node that is shutting down will try to migrate its servers to the peer. The only exception will be when the peer is also in a 'warning' or 'critical' state (which indicates an external issue, like low UPS batteries or an overtemperature event). In such a case, the server that is shutting down will gracefully shut down servers running on it.
SWITCHES
--local
Shut this machine down.
--reason X
If set, the string passed in will be set in the stop reason column for servers that are shut down. The reason can not contain spaces or non-alpha-numeric characters. The default stop reason is 'clean', or 'shed-load' if '--shed-load' was used.
--shed-load
Picks a node to turn off based on the above criteria.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program deletes an #!string!brand_0004!# from the #!string!brand_0002!# configuration file. If 'virt-manager' is installed and if 'tools::striker-configure-vmm::enabled = 1', the nodes for the deleted #!string!brand_0004!# will be removed from any system user's virtual machine manager the next time they log into the desktop.
NOTE
This does NOT delete the #!string!brand_0004!# from the peer dashboard! This will need to be called on each dashboard before they are sync'ed or else the deleted #!string!brand_0004!# will come back.
SWITCHES
--anvil
This is the name of the #!string!brand_0004!# to delete.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT
#!string!brand_0012!#
#!string!brand_0001!#
Backing up: [#!variable!source!#] to: [#!variable!destination!#].
#!variable!this_file!# has started.
Deleting the #!string!brand_0004!# named: [#!variable!anvil!#] with ID: [#!variable!anvil_id!#].
Must be called with '--anvil <name>'.
The #!string!brand_0004!# called: [#!variable!anvil!#] was not found in: [#!data!path::striker_config!#]

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This takes a command and runs it sometime in the future, redirecting output from the call to a temporary file. This is done using a random token given to the initial caller and then adding itself to crontab. When called again with that token via crontab, it deletes itself from cron and then executes the requested command, writing out any output to: '/tmp/token.<token>.txt'.
NOTE
When called without a token, the generated token out command output file will be printed;
token: [<string>] output: [</path/to/file>]
Note that the output should match above, but the parser should handle an arbitrary number of spaces between ':' and '['.
The 'output' file will terminate with a single line containing 'sdr-rc:X' where 'X' is the called program's return code.
SWITCHES
--call '/path/to/call [args]'
This is the command to call. If your command uses single-quotes in the argument list, escape them.
--delay <seconds>
This is the number of second to delay. Note that it gets rounded up to the next even minute, which is crontab's resolution. For example, if this is set to '30' and the time in 10:22:45, the delay will set to 10:23:15, then rounded up to 10:24:00.
The primary goal is to ensure that if a command needs to be coordinated between machines, assuming the machines are in time sync, they will all run at the same time. So the delay acts as a buffer of sorts in case the caller is requesting a delay very close to the start of the next minute (ie: it sets the delay at 10:22:59 on one machine and 10:23:01 on another, they would trigger one minute apart with no delay).
If you don't care about coordinating actions, you can ignore this and the call will happen within one minute.
--token <string>
This is the token used for the run. Normally the caller will never set this as it is generated automatically and used in the crontab file.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT
#!string!brand_0012!#
#!string!brand_0001!#
Crontab line: [#!variable!line!#] has our token: [#!variable!token!#], removing it.
Rewrote the crontab file to remove our entry.
Added the entry: [#!variable!crontab_string!#] to crontab.
Called with token: [#!variable!token!#], beginning run of delayed call.
Must be called with '--call "</path/to/call [args]>"'.
The requested call: [#!variable!call!#] seems to match the existing entry: [#!variable!line!#]. This is usually caused by a bug in a program calling is too many times.
#!variable!this_file!# has started.
The run is finished.
Writing out the new jobs file: [#!data!path::anvil-jobs!#] with still-queued job(s).
No queued jobs left, removing the jobs file: [#!data!path::anvil-jobs!#].
Writing out the new jobs file: [#!data!path::anvil-jobs!#] with the aborted job(s) removed.
There was a malformed line in the queue: [#!variable!line!#]. It has been removed.

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program is designed to run once per minute from cron. When it runs, it looks to see if #!data!path::anvil-jobs!# exists.
If it doesn't, the program exits. If it does, it is read in and parsed. The format is:
<time>:<token>:'<command {args}>'
The 'time' field is a unix time stamp. If the current time is equal to or greater than the time stamp, the command is run. If not, it is left in the queue for later.
The token is used to track the job and is used to generate the file where the call's STDOUT is written. Once a job is started, it is removed from the queue. If no jobs are left, the jobs file is removed.
NOTE
Jobs are queued by AN::Tools::Remote->synchronous_command_run(). This is not meant to be used by other tools or applications, though there should be no harm in doing so.
SWITCHES
--abort <string>
This will remove the queued job with the matching string (usually the token, but the command could be used as well). Note that if the job has already started, it will NOT be cancelled.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT
#!string!brand_0012!#
#!string!brand_0001!#
#!variable!this_file!# has started.
Not running as 'root', unable to control system daemons.
Asked to set a daemon: [#variable!daemon!#] to: [#!variable!state!#]. Either the daemon is not recognized or the state is not allowed.
Failed to start: [#!variable!daemon!#], rolling back.
Failed to stop: [#!variable!daemon!#], rolling back.

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program enables and disables the 'Install Target' feature. It does this primarily by turning dhcpd on and off, and adjusting the firewall as needed.
SWITCHES
--disable
Disable the install target feature. If it is already disabled, it does nothing and exits with a success.
--enable
Enable the install target feature. If it is already enabled, it does nothing and exits with a success.
--state, --status
Shows whether the install target feature is currently enabled or not.
Note: Regardless of the language used, the state/status will always print 'state:X' which callers can parse.
0 = Stopped 1 = Running 2 = Unknown state (error)
Note: If the program hits an error, it will exit with 'rc:X'. Consult the program header to determine what error codes mean. A message relating to the fault will be logged and printed to STDOUT.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT
#!string!brand_0012!#
#!string!brand_0001!#
Install target is currently enabled.
Install target is currently disabled.
Install target is currently unknown.
Install target is now enabled.
Install target is now disabled.
Successfully started: [#!variable!daemon!#].
Successfully stopped: [#!variable!daemon!#].

DESCRIPTION
This program shuts down the requested server. It uses the logic in AN::Tools::Cman->stop_server() to shut down the targer server via an ACPI power button event.
SWITCHES
--server <name>
This is the name of the server to shut down.
--reason <reason>
This allows you to set a specific 'stop reason' in the ScanCore database. If not specified, the stop reason will be 'clean'.
-h, -?, --help
Show this dialoge and exit.
SUPPORT

#!string!brand_0001!#
#!variable!this_file!# has started.
The run is finished.
The server you wish to boot must be specified via '--server <name>'. See --help for more information.
Failed to connect to any #!string!brand_0019!# databases. Please (carefully) boot using the 'clusvcadm' command directly.

-=] #!string!brand_0004!# - #!string!brand_0002!#
DESCRIPTION
This program boots the requested server. It uses the logic in AN::Tools::Cman->boot_server() to determine where, and if, to actually boot the server. It does nothing more on it's own.
SWITCHES
